text: I don't necessarily believe in fate but
if I hadn't broken my foot if I hadn't
been running so slow it wouldn't have
been where I was when the bombs went off
and hit me right in the left ear it's a
distinctive sound I can pick it up I can
replay it and at that point in time
Natalie's eyes got as big as saucers her
pupils dilated dad I've got to be there
last year at the marathon I had set out
the goal to run with my father which was
probably going to be our last
father-daughter race we've been running
together for about 10 years natalie is
one of our five children and we became
empty nesters about two years ago so
there's a few things that we like to do
with our kids to kind of keep connected
with them and you know we ran the whole
race together then we were separated at
mile 26 when the bombs went off I just
saw her wave and dad this way this way
her ponytail bobbing in the crowd and
just disappeared when a police officer
actually was able to stop me I yelled at
him and I said I am a physician I'm a
doctor you have to let me help and
that's when I saw you know a young woman
on the ground lifeless me and a group of
other first responders tried to save her
then I ended up treating for other
people with lower extremity injuries and
fortunately those other four survived
suddenly there was my face on the front
of a magazine and it said Boston's best
I finally realized that my life was
going to be different the anger that is
there has been far overshadowed in a way
by the compassion and I could either
embrace that difference or I could
continue to let it destroy my life and I
then chose this path where I decided to
embrace it I've pretty much been waking
up every day saying is it Marathon
Monday yet please what have you marathon
one day it had to be another race
another time to kind of finally close
that chapter of all the events that took
place when all the cameras go away and
when this story is no longer the story
we're still here people are still
suffering and people still have lost and
I feel a big sense of responsibility now
to keep helping people heal
